tn.ref: Zophar the Naamathite
tn.text: Translate this man's name as in [[:en:bible:notes:job:02:11|2:11]]. AT: "Zophar from the region of Naamah" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])

tn.ref: Should not such a multitude of words be answered?
tn.text: Zophar is asking a question in the negative to emphasize that Job's words must be challenged. AT: "We must answer all of these words!" or "Someone would respond to all these words" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

tn.ref: Should this man, so full of talk, be believed?
tn.text: Zophar uses this question to emphasize that they should not believe what Job was saying. AT: "This man is so full of talk, but he people should not believe him" or "Your many words alone do not mean you are innocent." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

tn.ref: Should your boasting make others remain silent?
tn.text: Zophar uses this question to rebuke Job. AT: "Just because you have spoken many words, this does not mean that others must keep silent." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

tn.ref: When you mock our teaching, will no one make you feel ashamed?
tn.text: Zophar uses this question to rebuke Job. AT: "You have mocked our teaching. Now we will make you feel ashamed!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

tn.ref: My beliefs are pure
tn.text: "My understanding is correct,"

tn.ref: I am blameless in your eyes
tn.text: The eyes represent sight, which is a metaphor for God's evaluation of Job. Possible meanings are 1) that Job is saying that God judges him as blameless. AT: "You say that I am blameless" or 2) that Job believes he has been blameless and that God should judge him as blameless. AT: "You should recognize that I am blameless" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: that God would speak ... open his lips against you
tn.text: The words "open his lips" are a metonym that means speak. These two phrases mean the same thing are are used together to emphasize Zophar's desire that God would speak harshly against Job. . (See:  and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]] )

tn.ref: that he would show ... secrets of wisdom
tn.text: What the "secrets of wisdom" are can be stated clearly. AT: "that he would show you that you are suffering because of your sin"  (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

tn.ref: God demands from you less than your iniquity deserves
tn.text: Demanding from Job represents punishing Job. AT: "God is punishing you less than you deserve" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: Can you understand God by searching for him? Can you comprehend the Almighty perfectly?
tn.text: These two parallel questions are asking the same thing. The writer uses the form of a question to add emphasis. AT: "You cannot understand God by searching for him, and you will never completely understand the Almighty!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

tn.ref: The matter
tn.text: This refers to understanding God. AT: "To understand God" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

tn.ref: is as high as heaven ... deeper than Sheol
tn.text: The impossibility of understanding God is spoken of as if it were impossible to go to these extremely far away place. AT: "is as inaccessible as the highest places in heaven ... is more inaccessible than the deepest places in Sheol" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])

tn.ref: what can you do?
tn.text: Zophar uses this question to show that a person cannot do anything to understand God fully. AT: "you cannot do anything" or "you cannot understand him fully" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

tn.ref: what can you know
tn.text: Zophar uses this question to show that a person cannot do anything to know God fully. AT: "You cannot know God fully" or "you cannot know all there is to know" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

tn.ref: Its measure
tn.text: Possible meanings are that this refers to 1) God's greatness or 2) the greatness of God's wisdom

tn.ref: is longer than the earth ... wider than the sea
tn.text: God's greatness or wisdom is spoken of as if the could be measured in distance. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: If he ... shuts anyone up
tn.text: "If God ... shuts anyone up in prison"

tn.ref: if he calls anyone to judgment
tn.text: The abstract noun "judgment" can be translated with the verb "judge." AT: "if God calls anyone to go to him so that God might judge him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])

tn.ref: who can stop him
tn.text: This question emphasizes that no one can stop God. AT: "No one can stop him!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

tn.ref: does he not notice it?
tn.text: This emphasizes that God does notice sin. AT: "He surely notices it!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

tn.ref: But foolish people have no understanding
tn.text: The abstract noun "understanding" can be expressed with the verb "understand." AT: "But foolish people do not understand" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])

tn.ref: they will get it when a wild donkey gives birth to a man
tn.text: Since a wild donkey can never give birth to a man, this means that foolish people will never get understanding. AT: "only if a wild donkey could give birth to a man could foolish people get understanding" or "it is as impossible for a foolish person to get understanding as it is for a donkey to give birth to a man" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_irony]])

tn.ref: suppose that you had set your heart right
tn.text: The heart represents thoughts and attitudes. Setting it right represents correcting it. AT: "even if you had corrected your attitude" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: and had reached out with your hands toward God
tn.text: This is a symbolic action representing asking God for help. AT: "and had made an appeal and prayed to God" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_symaction]])

tn.ref: suppose that iniquity were in your hand
tn.text: The hand represents what a person does. AT: "even if you had done some evil things in the past" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: but that then you put it far away from you
tn.text: Putting sin behind represents stopping sinning. AT "but that then you stopped doing evil things" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: did not let unrighteousness live in your tents
tn.text: Unrighteousness living represents people doing unrighteous things. AT: "and you did not allow the members of your household to do unrighteous things" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])

tn.ref: lift up your face without a sign of shame
tn.text: "Lifting up your face" represents the attitude of a person who is confident and brave. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

tn.ref: you would remember it only like waters that have flowed away
tn.text: Zophar is comparing misery with water that flows downstream and it is gone. AT: "You would remember it, but the misery will be gone, like waters that have flowed away" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])

tn.ref: Your life would ... like the morning.
tn.text: Zophar repeats the same idea for emphasis. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])

tn.ref: Your life would be brighter than the noonday
tn.text: Brightness represents being prosperous and happy. AT: "Your life would be prosperous and happy like the noonday" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: though there were darkness
tn.text: Darkness represents troubles and sadness. AT: "Though there were dark troubles and sadness" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_hypo]])

tn.ref: it would become like the morning
tn.text: The morning represents light, which represents prosperity and happiness. AT: "it would be prosperous and happy like the morning" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: You would be secure ... take your rest in safety
tn.text: Zophar repeats the same idea for emphasis and describes the possibility. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_hypo]])

tn.ref: would take your rest in safety
tn.text: "Take your rest" is an idiom for "rest." The phrase "in safety" can be expressed with the word "safely." AT: "would rest safely" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])

tn.ref: Also you would lie down in rest ... your favor.
tn.text: Zophar repeats the same idea for emphasis and describes the possibility. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_hypo]])

tn.ref: you would lie down in rest
tn.text: The abstract noun "rest" can be expressed with the verb "rest." AT: "you would lie down and rest" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])

tn.ref: the eyes of wicked people will fail
tn.text: Their eyes represent their understanding. AT: "the understanding of the wicked people will fail" or "the wicked people will not be able to understand" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])

tn.ref: Their only hope will be a last gasp of life
tn.text: The abstract noun "hope" can be expressed with the verb "hope." The last gasp of life represents dying. AT: "Their only hope will be to breath their final breath" or "They will only hope to die" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
